reviewText:
EDGE
A great little puzzle game that requires quick reactions and some lateral thinking.

Rating 6/10

The main objective of EDGE is to traverse your cube through some ingenious and rather convoluted levels made up of blocks, buttons and platforms whilst avoiding all manners of death as quickly as possible. Picking up small prisms that are dotted around the level speeds up your cube and gives you a higher rating for completing a level. There is also the ability to perform 'edge time' by balancing your cube on one of it's edges which allows you to hang off the side of walls. It's a mixture of balance and timing but it rewards you with time reduction at the end of the level.

Each new level, of which there are over eighty, represents a new challenge and new gameplay mechanics, learning these new mechanics is fairly simple as there are clues along the way. Its success lies in its simplicity. Get your cube from point A to point B in the fastest time you can manage.

It can be frustrating at times and there are a couple of fiendishly tricky sequences that can verge on annoying/frustrating but it's also incredibly addictive and rewarding.

It's not a traditional puzzle game nor is it platform game, it's something in between and it's great fun.

————CONTROLS————
Before I start I want to talk about the controls because thats what most of the thumbs-down say aren’t good. Luckily in the settings there is a way you can change this. The default is more for left-handers, but you can change it for right-handers in the settings. It’s called North-west or North-east something like that. Once you have it set your way there should be no problem at all. If you’ve ever played Bloxorz you should have no problem.

————GRAPHICS————
Ok now about the graphics, what made me want to buy this was defiantly because of the clean and colourful design. The movements and animations are smooth and the cube is beautiful. A comment said “ letting you’re cube flash won’t make your game better “ Maybe thats true but the flashing cube sure made me want to buy this.

————GAMEPLAY————
You are a cube that has to reach the end platform for each level. You use AWSD or up down left right to control yourself around obstacles. Now the game is called EDGE for a reason, they had a great idea of you balancing on your edge to stick to the sides of platforms. If you do it right you can hang on for 10 sec and beyond. Normally 5 average for me, which is enough to get past all the levels.

————RE-SPAWN / CHECKPOINTS————
Thank you, thank you for having this or I would have stopped playing after half and hour. This game is based on speed which means your ranking and score is based on the time you took to complete each level. I usually get the lowest score LOL, but I’m just glad I finish it. The thing is you can almost respawn after each mistake, each checkpoint is only like 2 meters apart so you can finish a level even if you suck.

———— READ THIS————
Now here is where I want to talk about this game. YOU HAVE NO GOAL. NO SATISFACTION.
Humans like to think they accomplished something, even if it is the stupidest thing. Maybe its about their reaction time, or how smart they are. If they beat a level they thought was a challenge, they would want to play more. It is a complicated balance - hard enough to be a goal but not too hard to make them quit.

You see, you saved your game by giving all the checkpoints, that is sweet. But now to the game play!!! All those fancy platforms flying around and transforming is just a pain in the ♥♥♥. It has no help to the player and nothing to do with the game. It’s just like showing off fancy graphics, so yeah , I have to wait 10 seconds for this platform to come over just so I can go on it and take me to the next platform. I’d rather just walk on a bridge to the next place.
The thing is it doesn’t help and is annoying.

Also something I wanted to say is that you have these random blocks fall out / push me /transform in random directions, and you somehow assume the player is going to know your crazy moves on their first attempt.
What happens is I die 5 times. Yeah ok, I know the pattern now so its simple and thats it! So easy!! The player does no feel a challenge because it wasn’t, It was just frustrating. And at the end it was easy because I died so I know how to do it now.

!!!NO!!! you must let the player think they can do it on their first attempt !!
LET them think they can do better !
Not you NOT the developers. Make obstacles that actually have a pattern.
Let the player know there is danger ahead. Let them see how they can avoid something as long as they think fast enough!

THIS GAME COULD HAVE BEEN SO INTERESTING!
It’s not that pleasant to right a long review, But I actually care about this game. Thats why I made sure I played all the basic levels before commenting on it. I just wanted you to know how much better this could be, and I love the edge time concept. You can add in a release button. Sometimes I’m stuck on the wall and I want to let go, but I can’t. reviewText:
EDGE Review
Curation text - With deceivingly difficult puzzles and an excellent soundtrack, EDGE is a mind-bending puzzler for the ages. 9/10


DIFFICULTYEDGE is a medium difficulty game. All the puzzles have one or two tricky parts, but you'll have more difficulty because of the camera angle than the actual level. You will need to use the top-down map to get through these parts, as sometimes your own block obscures obstacles or holes. One of the hardest parts of the game is hanging on to the edges of blocks, but more about that later.


ISSUESThis game, as I mentioned before, suffers from a camera perspective issue. This affects the game mostly when you have to differentiate between blocks of different levels and heights. As of now, you can work with this mostly as a trial-and-error situation. However, it makes speed runs or flawless runs very difficult.


PERFORMANCEI tested this game in both integrated graphics (Intel HD 4600) and dedicated graphics (GeForce GTX 860M 2GB). The performance of the game was phenomenal with both types. It ran well both in 1080p full screen and 900p windowed. Even on dedicated graphics, the game didn't generate too much heat. There were no unexpected crashes in my experience. Another game by the same developer, Rush, suffers from huge performance issues, an I'm pleased to see that the devs have really stepped up their game (no pun intended) with EDGE.


SOUNDTRACKPersonally, I loved the 8-bit feel of the game's sound. It is not distracting from the game in any way, and is in general just really enjoyable to hear. One thing to point out is that this game can be played 100% without the sound, making a great quick-fix game when you don't have headphones available.


GAMEPLAYIn EDGE, you are a block that can pivot on its edges onto other blocks. You can also hang onto moving blocks, shrink down in size and scale walls, and find shortcuts on many levels. The hanging-on-moving-blocks is fairly difficult; when you progress into the game, many of the movement times get longer and therefore harder to hold onto. To complete each level, you have to find your way to the end while collecting colorful cubes along the way. Some cubes are significantly harder to find than others, but it is not necessary to find all of them to pass a level. At the end of each level, you are assigned a grade based on your time, number of failed attempts, and cubes found. You'll find yourself constantly replaying levels just to get the highest grade you can.


OVERVIEWEDGE is without a doubt one of the most fun and addicting platformers I have played. Although it is fairly short, it has great replay value and once you start, you'll want to keep playing.

Aspect        Rating                Difficulty        7                Performance        10                Gameplay        10                Graphics        8                Issues        6                Overall        8
TL;DRI got this game on sale for under a buck. It was a phenomenal deal. This puzzler has plenty of levels and is challenging enough to keep you playing, failure after failure. Having played this dev's other games (Toki Tori and RUSH), I can say that this one is probably my favorite. Great deal on sale, but still worth the whole 8 bucks if you like puzzle games.

reviewText:
What's great about EDGE is that the solutions are not exclusive; they're multiple in possibility. Our goal is to decide the best way to execute the solution, and then put it into motion. It's a puzzle of action, more than traditional puzzles which only exercise intellect.

A good amount of skill is certainly required to master the cube, as its shape and weight make its movement distinct to the game.

There's a ranking system per level, and some not-so-hidden areas (see the map on the upper left) so that gives you lots of replay value as you strive to earn the highest ranking. Any game that encourages you to keep practicing is doing something right.

You'll be ripping your hair out as early as Level 10 ('Metro' will mess you up). It's a grand opportunity to practice patience, persistence and perseverance.

Definite recommendation for puzzle lovers and enthusiasts. Bonus for music lovers: the soundtrack is gorgeous. It gives each level personality, as the platforms move appropriately as if to the beat.

reviewText:
Live on the edge, and be sure to hang on tight!
EDGE is a puzzle game at its core, but it also has a great set-up for speedrunners. You play as a cube with one main goal: get to the end of each level. In some stages, this is simple. In others, prepare for an onslaught of obstacles that will push you to your limits. Both casual players and hardcore ones will find appeal in EDGE. Don't believe me? Take a look below to see everything it does right.

Pros:
EDGE has a grand total of 109 levels, all of them having unique traits and different ways of swiftly completing them. If you like the gameplay, you are not about to get bored.
Speaking of the gameplay, it's awesome. The few controls the game needs work flawlessly on the keyboard, which is what I used to play it. It is one of those delightful games that is quick to learn and difficult to master. Edge Time in particular can be very difficult to become good at. It may sound easy to tap a key and stay on the edge of a stage piece, but be warned, it is a lot harder than you might think.
The tutorials are well-constructed. In levels with new mechanics or potentially obscure paths, there are glowing squares to move your cube on. A ghost cube will appear to show you what to do. Thus, you can either watch the tutorials as many times as you want, or ignore them completely.
For a game like EDGE, the graphics do not need any sort of intensity. They are simplistic and they work perfectly. The colors are easy on the eyes and the levels look great.
I really enjoy the music. There are lots of catchy tracks, and the electronic theme throughout the soundtrack is fitting. They are a good pace for the gameplay, too.
Each level can get anywhere from a D-Rank to an S-Rank. Want to play the game leisurely? Ignore the scores and do as you will. Want to be an expert at it? Keep coming back and memorizing those levels. There is a fantastic amount of replaying potential, even after an S-Rank, because your best times will be saved!
The menus are crisp, clean, and easy to navigate. There are not too many options that you have to juggle between.
It runs smoothly. Not much space is needed for EDGE, and most computers will have no trouble with it.
There are achievements that range in difficulty. A lot of them can be gotten without too much trouble. Completing all of the levels with S-Ranks, though... I raise my nonexistent hat to anyone who can pull that one off.
The price is reasonable. I've put a lot of hours into EDGE, and for a base price of $7.99, you will get a lot of bang for your buck. Want to be cheap? You can wait for sale, where the Two Tribes bundle of four games (one being EDGE) is about $0.99. That's how I got EDGE, and I feel kind of dirty for that after experiencing how much fun it is.
Every time you enter the game, it says hi" to you. How nice of it! Not many games take the time to greet you.

reviewText:
This is one of those simple, straight forward puzzle games that doesn't try to do anything particularly amazing and instead focuses on delivering simply, good gameplay. The level design and pacing of the mechanics/timing go hand in hand and make for a fantastic, albeit very shallow learning curve where you're constantly trying to push on to the next level. EDGE generally doesn't have anything to rant nor rave about, but it's a good, solid, fun game, and that's often enough.

Highlights
What makes this better than average is its combination of sharp graphics and art-style, serene and ambient music and incredibly good level design. They serve to keep each level fun and keep frustration to a minimum and keep you engaged and wanting to get further.

* Originally designed as mobile game, the Steam version came with the removal of the FPS lock and full resolution, which shows a level of respect for the players and platform
* Simple, timeless design and graphics and a minimalist overlay and title screen mean this game wont feel out-dated for a long time

Mistakes
Two Tribes, who went far on the success of Toki Tori, are a small Dutch company who have worked on a ridiculously large range of platformers, and with a ton of big developers, and the polish and testing that you see in their games is the result of this. Everything works well and you'll be hard pushed to find mistakes, problems and things that take away from gameplay in their titles.

There are a few levels where you might be frustrated too much to continue, or suffer more than you want, but they're few and far between and actually add a higher level of challenge.

Recommendations
At £5.49/7.99€/$7.99 and with at least 4 hours of main gameplay across 100+ levels, and plenty more for completionists, EDGE has plenty of content, but may feel overpriced, especially when you consider the fairly simple mechanics. I'd recommend waiting for a -50% drop or more before picking it up.

EDGE is also available in the Two Tribes Classics Pack and Two Tribes Pack (which also includes Toki Tori 2+ for around double the price). Since Toki Tori 2+ is fairly poor, and both EDGE and Toki Tori are above average games, if you like the look of either of those two you will benefit from picking up the Classics Pack instead, especially when on sale.

* There're 4 hidden levels and an Edge Tool which you can use to edit game files and install new levels and add a bunch of new content.

'Edge' is an old-school fashioned isometric puzzle platformer.

Desc:
You are a cube and your goal is to reach the end platform to finish the level. Within the levels you are able to collect prisms. Some of the prisms are hidden in the level behind the surface or in certain areas of the level where you need to take a detour. The most interesting thing of 'Edge' is the flawless music combined with the creative level design.

Pros:
+ appropriate and flawless music
+ awesome and creative level design
+ no glitches
+ interesting help system (question mark at the floor of difficult areas which shows you how to solve this puzzle)
+ downloadable demo
+ 3 level stacks (normal, extended, bonus)
(+ achievements)

Cons:
(- level editor; but NO steam workshop)
(- leaderboard bugs; players who solved a level within 0:00 -.-)
(- sometimes you get confused with the keys ^^)

Recommended, even if it's not on sale, because of the awesome level design and the old-school atmosphere combined with the music which gives you a great feeling.

reviewText:
EDGE is a great little platform/puzzle game where you roll a cube around an isometric world formed out of blocks. Your task is to find and pick up a number of little 'prisms' scattered around the level, before making your way to the exit. This would be easy, if each level were not so precisely and fiendishly designed to hinder you in your mission.

EDGE originated on the iPhone where it had an innovative finger-slide control system. Luckily, it has not suffered from the conversion to desktop formats, and I found it easy to play with a joypad or keyboard.

The level design is the reason I am writing this review - it is masterful, with only a few mis-steps. The way the game establishes a language of cubes, switches and sliding blocks and then makes humour out of them needs to be experienced by any student of game design.

This is one of the few retro styled games that actually captures the spirit of 8-bit gaming as well as the appearance. It has the same kind of feeling as Nebulus or Marble Madness, and seems like the kind of game Ultimate: Play the Game would release if you sent a modern PC back in time to 1984.

I must mention the incredible soundtrack, which while completely modern, constantly recalls the sounds of 8-bit gaming, both Western and Japanese. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Somewhere on the edge of platformer and puzzle game sits... uhh, EDGE. It's kind of a puzzle platformer, but a lot of the puzzles are trial and error, and the lack of a jump button makes it hard to consider a platformer.
I'm really impressed at the creativity of the level design given the 5 or so distinct level design objects in this game, they really did their best to keep things fresh an interesting in that regard. Not even every level is that good, there are some pretty garbage ones, of course, but I never felt like I was playing the same thing over and over again. It's surprisingly diverse and there's some neat spectacle to be had as well.
That being said... the game isn't as fun as I wish it could be. I think this is mostly the fault of the physics engine, which seems mildly glitchy and not precise enough for some of the things you're asked to do. I've had instances of clipping through walls before, and aside from that there are many instances where holding a button for just the slightest bit too long gets you stuck on another object and prooobably pulled to your death in some way or another. It just leads to frustration. And sometimes the trial and error gets to be too much, too many things to learn between checkpoints or too much time between checkpoints. These aren't problems that every level has but a lot of them certainly do.
I also have no clue how to get good times on these stages, the S+ ranking seems strict even for what I'm used to; maybe I'm missing something or something wasn't explained to me, but there seems to be a huuuuge gap between getting A's on every level and getting S+ on every level. Oh well.
I did enjoy this game more than I disliked it, overall, but it's on the cautious side of positive, Considering that it seems to go on a pretty heavy discount during steam sales, though, I doubt you coudl do wrong picking it up for cheap.  And there's no lack of content to begin with, either. I can't think of any other game like it, as well, so it also has that going for it.

I have never in my whole life sworn at a game as much as I have at this game.   The controls infuriate me beyond belief.      I've read some of the other negative comments, but I have played isometric puzzlers since Ant Attack on the ZX81 and Marble Madness on the AtariST.  It's not the NW/NE/SW/SE thing that really irritates me (as it does others), it's the way the controls REACT DIFFERENTLY BASED ON THE AMOUNT OF STUFF ON THE SCREEN!!!

You're a cube, and unlike most cube games where you ROLL along nicely, in this game, there's inertia and proper physics.  Have you ever tried to ROLL a cube?  It's about as much fun as shaving your privates.  It's why the square wheel never really took off.

The Physics engine is tied to the frame rate, so when there's less on the screen, the cube reacts a lot faster to your controls, and falls back at a different rate too.  So a light tap on the up key in one part of a level might allow you to lift yourself gently and get some 'edge time', while at another, it'll flip you boldy completely over two tiles and into the chasm.

The name, and the point of the game are to 'hang' on your 'edges', but hanging on edges is  so flipping HARD with keys.  I've worn a little gap in the surface of my down arrow repeatedly trying to get the 60 second edge-time achievement (bloody hard).

So, What do I think about the game?  It's music and aesthetics are okay..  The controls are clunky, variable, and highly annoying.    The level design is interesting and sometimes actually fun.

Would I recommend this game?  If you haven't played Rush yet, yes.  If you've already played Rush, then this will be more of the same, with a much more irritating control system.   The only thing which really makes this stand out are the mobile levels which 'morph' on the click of a button.  That was fun.. But the 'click a button, then dodge a piece of flying platform' mechanic gets old.

Yes, if this game is a few quid, get it, play it, then move on.  I'd give it a 'Meh' out of 10.

ADVICE: Play this game on a high-end PC and frame limit it to 60fps.  Then the controls will at least be uniform across the game.

Edge is easy to learn and understand but has a good deal of complexity and attention to detail. It looks clean and sharp. One relatively minor physics detail caught my eye: when your cube is immediately between two walls, you can't climb those walls, since a cube can't roll away when it's in a cubic hole. Makes sense, and a lesser developer might have overlooked that.
The 8-bit soundtrack is fun. It's just like the rest of the game: simple on the surface but surprisingly deep and complex. It's catchy -- I caught some friends humming or whistling along as I played.

The puzzles do a good job of keeping you guessing. Just when you've got it figured out, there's a neat little twist and you have to reevaluate. Some of the puzzle themes are also pretty neat — there's a subway-themed level and a robot one. Plus, the three different categories of levels have distinct feels to them. The normal levels are basically a race to the finish where you try to die as little as possible. The extra levels provide more intellectual puzzles rather than speed or reaction based ones, with many levels featuring a face-off against the sinister dark cube.
There's a good degree of replayability for completionists: cubes collected, deaths, and speed all factor into your rating for a track, so to get the elusive S+ rating,  you'll really need to work to figure out the optimal path and timings.

Edge is a borderline solid platform game. The strongest aspect of the game is the creative use of theming of the levels; from such a simplistic graphic standpoint Edge gets really creative with the level design, using the cubic platforms for robots, gears, birds, statues, flags, snakes, you name it. That's the big draw of the game, and it's really cool to explore them all.

However coupled with the outstanding elements are some minor problems that do affect the enjoyment to some degree. The main problem is the key configuration. Edge is designed around a diagonal, isometric point of view so every move the cube makes is in a diagonal direction. Unfortunately the controls revolve around ASDW or the arrow keys, which simulate typical Up-Down-Left-Right movements, which can cause some confusion.

One game-related problem is the poor use of checkpoints. You can't see the checkpoints but if you happen to die then the game will bring you back to a certain point in the level so you don't end up starting the entire level again. The only problem is that sometimes the checkpoints will take you a little further than where you died, or take you back to a point where you have to redo an unfairly large chunk of the level.

The other problem is the platforming, which is a bit serious. If you collect a prism then your cube moves at a fluent and quick pace for a brief amount of time, however normally the cube feels very sluggish and makes things like edge climbing and falling very taxing. There's also the problem with the moving platforms, which can cause some shenanigans. When you make the cube fall onto a moving platform, depending on where the cube fell onto it, sometimes the cube doesn't get carried with the platform and results in you just falling and dying.

Overall I did find this game to be fun, and as a fun fact the game runs at a perfect 60 frames here in comparison to the 3DS eShop version, where the framerate always drops significantly. HOWEVER! Due to the quirkiness of the platform controls the game will take some getting used to, for better or for worse.

Edge is a puzzle platformer in which you navigate your cube through isometric levels that grow in size and difficulty...

:[ I purchased this game on sale therefore my opinion on value for money is void ]:

I feel that Edge is comparable to Super Meat Boy and at the same time not. The Difficulty in Super Meat Boy comes from the growing complexity of levels and the eventual precision to survive some of the more demanding levels. I do however feel I have got more frustrated with Edge though.

The main reason for this is the type of obstacles. Unlike Super Meat Boy where the danger is visible and conspicuous, In Edge it is not. I have died many times to unexpected movements and blocks causing me to fall or get crushed. It became more a game of trial and error and preparing for the movements after previous failures which was not exactly what I was looking for when I picked this title up.

I do however love the graphical style and OST. It is polished, runs well and the amount of gameplay you can get out of the game on a casual level is great. The additional mechanics that are introduced as you get to the more complex levels really make this game standout.
